paragraphs: Taupō, or Taupō-nui-a-Tia in Māori, is located on the shores of Lake Taupō, New Zealand’s largest lake, formed by a massive volcanic eruption. It has been a significant site for Māori for centuries.
European exploration began in the 1800s, and Taupō gradually developed as a tourism and forestry center.
Today, Taupō is known for trout fishing, geothermal attractions, and as a gateway to Tongariro National Park. The lake and surrounding mountains draw visitors year-round.
